awd_titl_txt: ERI: Epilepsy in Women: Monitoring and Management using Noninvasive Wearable Sensors
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Almost 1% of the world's population lives with epilepsy and half of them are women, whose seizures and antiseizure medicines affect their menstrual cycle, pregnancy, menopause, and bone health. Hormonal changes in women can influence seizure risk and are associated with changes in biological signals measured by wearable devices, such as temperature and heart rate variability, and can be linked to seizure patterns. This Engineering Research Initiation (ERI) award focuses on improving the quality of life of women with epilepsy by creating forecasting algorithms that can help manage dosing of antiseizure medication based on predicted seizure risk. The proposed research will provide training opportunities for a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students and the focus will be to engage female students in research. 

The proposed research investigates hormonal changes associated with the menstrual cycle and their effects on seizure risk in women by analyzing physiological signals recorded with non-invasive wearable devices. The ability to forecast seizures, minutes to hours in advance has already been verified using data from invasive EEG (Electroencephalography) devices; however, it is still a challenge to do this using noninvasive wearable devices. The performance of the machine learning algorithms for seizure forecasting could be significantly improved if the seizure risk associated with hormonal changes be considered in the design to mitigate false alarms and improve sensitivity. Designing a reliable seizure forecasting algorithm will allow patients to use lower baseline doses of medications, with escalated doses given during times of high seizure risk. Additionally, investigating the gender-specific parameters affecting seizure risk and implementing them in managing epilepsy will lead to significant improvements in quality of life for women with epilepsy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Approximately one percent of the US population is affected by epilepsy, with half of this number being female. Despite the application of various treatment techniques, such as medication therapy and resective surgery, many individuals with epilepsy continue to experience seizures. A reliable seizure forecasting algorithm has the potential to enhance the quality of life for people with epilepsy by enabling them to modify their activities or take fast-acting medication in response to predicted seizures.

Recent advancements in wearable technology have demonstrated the feasibility of seizure forecasting through the implementation of machine learning techniques. Previous research indicates that the temporal distribution of seizures is non-random, and the risk of seizure occurrence can be forecasted in some people. In particular, hormonal changes in women exhibit a non-random and cyclic nature as well, and it is known that hormonal changes influence brain excitability and can modulate seizure risk. However, this has remained largely unstudied despite the importance of this phenomenon.

The hormonal changes in women are associated with measurable changes in bio-signals such as temperature and heart rate variability. This study correlates hormonal changes and bio-signals using data recorded from non-invasive devices during the menstrual cycle. Continuous data from 21 healthy female subjects, wearing wristbands for at least two menstrual cycles and tracking their menstruation and ovulation days, revealed that, in addition to temperature and heart rate variability, skin conductance level can also serve as a representative indicator of hormonal changes.

Machine learning algorithms were developed to accurately track menstrual cycle phases, achieving a 91% accuracy in detecting menses, ovulation, and luteal phase. The application of these algorithms to data collected from patients with epilepsy (”My Seizure Gauge” project funded by Epilepsy Foundation of America), allowed for the detection of menstrual phases and recognition of ovulating and non-ovulating patients. Mapping menstrual phases and seizure cycles suggests a correlation between hormonal changes and seizure patterns in some patients. Furthermore, the analysis of data from male subjects contributes to defining differences in natural cycles.

Intellectual merit and broader impacts: These findings hold the potential to better manage the health of patients with epilepsy, offering insights that may improve their quality of life. Additionally, automating the tracking of menstrual cycle phases, especially ovulation, can alleviate the need for traditional methods like urine strip tests or thermometers. This automation is not only beneficial for epilepsy patients but also holds relevance for broader studies related to women's physical and mental health. As a result, the impact of this interdisciplinary project extends across various disciplines focused on women's health.

Thus far, the project has generated several publications and presentations, with additional papers currently in progress. Three female graduate students and two undergraduate students from the departments of Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, and Data Science underwent training, enhancing their expertise in data science, signal processing, and artificial intelligence. Furthermore, the acquired devices will be utilized in the physiological signal processing course and other associated research endeavors.
